TypeSignature.Value: public abstract class ValidatorHandler : Java.Lang.Object, IDisposable, Org.Xml.Sax.IContentHandler
.class public auto ansi abstract beforefieldinit ValidatorHandler extends Java.Lang.Object implements class Android.Runtime.IJavaObject, class Org.Xml.Sax.IContentHandler, class System.IDisposable

Docs.summary: Streaming validator that works on SAX stream.

remarks.para: Streaming validator that works on SAX stream.
A object is a thread-unsafe, non-reentrant object. In other words, it is the application's responsibility to make sure that one object is not used from more than one thread at any given time.
checks if the SAX events follow the set of constraints described in the associated , and additionally it may modify the SAX events (for example by adding default values, etc.)

extends from , but it refines the underlying in the following way:
startElement/endElement events must receive non-null String for uri, localName, and qname, even though SAX allows some of them to be null. Similarly, the user-specified will receive non-null Strings for all three parameters.
Applications must ensure that 's and are invoked properly. Similarly, the user-specified will receive startPrefixMapping/endPrefixMapping events. If the introduces additional namespace bindings, the user-specified will receive additional startPrefixMapping/endPrefixMapping events.
for the method may or may not include xmlns* attributes.

A is automatically reset every time the startDocument method is invoked.
Recognized Properties and Features

This spec defines the following feature that must be recognized by all implementations.
http://xml.org/sax/features/namespace-prefixes

This feature controls how a introduces namespace bindings that were not present in the original SAX event stream. When this feature is set to true, it must make sure that the user's will see the corresponding xmlns* attribute in the object of the
callback. Otherwise, xmlns* attributes must not be added to that's passed to the user-specified .
(Note that regardless of this switch, namespace bindings are always notified to applications through and methods of the specified by the user.)
Note that this feature does NOT affect the way a receives SAX events. It merely changes the way it augments SAX events.
This feature is set to false by default.

Docs.summary: Gets the which receives the augmented validation result.

remarks.para:
Get method documentation [Android Documentation]
Gets the which receives the augmented validation result.

Set method documentation [Android Documentation]
Sets the which receives the augmented validation result.
When a is specified, a will work as a filter and basically copy the incoming events to the specified .
In doing so, a may modify the events, for example by adding defaulted attributes.
A may buffer events to certain extent, but to allow to be used by a parser, the following requirement has to be met.
When , , , or
are invoked on a , the same method on the user-specified must be invoked for the same event before the callback returns.
may not introduce new elements that were not present in the input.
may not remove attributes that were present in the input.
When a callback method on the specified throws an exception, the same exception object must be thrown from the . The should not be notified of such an exception.
This method can be called even during a middle of a validation.

MemberSignature.Value: public virtual bool GetFeature (string name);
.method public hidebysig newslot virtual instance bool GetFeature(string name) cil managed

Docs.param: The feature name, which is a non-null fully-qualified URI.
Docs.summary: Look up the value of a feature flag.

remarks.para: Look up the value of a feature flag.

The feature name is any fully-qualified URI. It is possible for a to recognize a feature name but temporarily be unable to return its value. Some feature values may be available only in specific contexts, such as before, during, or after a validation.
Implementors are free (and encouraged) to invent their own features, using names built on their own URIs.

Docs.exception: If the feature value can't be assigned or retrieved.
When the recognizes the feature name but cannot determine its value at this time.
When the name parameter is null.

Docs.param: The property name, which is a non-null fully-qualified URI.
Docs.summary: Look up the value of a property.

remarks.para: Look up the value of a property.

The property name is any fully-qualified URI. It is possible for a to recognize a property name but temporarily be unable to return its value. Some property values may be available only in specific contexts, such as before, during, or after a validation.
s are not required to recognize any specific property names.
Implementors are free (and encouraged) to invent their own properties, using names built on their own URIs.

Docs.exception: If the property value can't be assigned or retrieved.
When the XMLReader recognizes the property name but cannot determine its value at this time.
When the name parameter is null.

Docs.summary: Gets the current set to this .

remarks.para:
Get method documentation [Android Documentation]
Gets the current set to this .

Set method documentation [Android Documentation]
Sets the to customize resource resolution while in a validation episode.
uses a when it needs to locate external resources while a validation, although exactly what constitutes "locating external resources" is up to each schema language.
When the is null, the implementation will behave as if the following is set:
class DumbLSResourceResolver implements LSResourceResolver { public LSInput resolveResource( String publicId, String systemId, String baseURI) {
return null; // always return null } }
If a throws a (or instances of its derived classes), then the will abort the parsing and the caller of the validate method will receive the same .
When a new object is created, initially this field is set to null.

Docs.param: The feature name, which is a non-null fully-qualified URI.
The requested value of the feature (true or false).
Docs.summary: Set the value of a feature flag.

remarks.para: Set the value of a feature flag.
Feature can be used to control the way a parses schemas, although s are not required to recognize any specific property names.

The feature name is any fully-qualified URI. It is possible for a to expose a feature value but to be unable to change the current value. Some feature values may be immutable or mutable only in specific contexts, such as before, during, or after a validation.

Docs.exception: If the feature value can't be assigned or retrieved.
When the recognizes the feature name but cannot set the requested value.
When the name parameter is null.

s are not required to recognize setting any specific property names.

MemberSignature.Value: protected override Type ThresholdType { get; }
.property instance class System.Type ThresholdType

Docs.summary: This API supports the Mono for Android infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
Docs.value: A which provides the declaring type.

remarks.para: This property is used to control virtual vs. non virtual method dispatch against the underlying JNI object. When this property is equal to the declaring type, then virtual method invocation against the JNI object is performed; otherwise, we assume that the method was overridden by a derived type, and perform non-virtual methdo invocation.

MemberSignature.Value: public abstract Javax.Xml.Validation.TypeInfoProvider TypeInfoProvider { get; }
.property instance class Javax.Xml.Validation.TypeInfoProvider TypeInfoProvider

remarks.para: Obtains the implementation of this .
The obtained can be queried during a parse to access the type information determined by the validator.

Some schema languages do not define the notion of type, for those languages, this method may not be supported. However, to be compliant with this specification, implementations for W3C XML Schema 1.0 must support this operation.
